awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Intra-Urban Variability in Carbon Deposition: Rates, Pathways, and Determinants
awd_abstract_narration:
NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION
GEOGRAPHY SPATIAL SCIENCES (GSS) PROGRAM

ABSTRACT

This Faculty Early-Career Development (CAREER) award will support research that will contribute new knowledge about urban carbon cycle science by assessing the role of vegetation in the capture, cycling, and fate of carbon in urban environments.  As a major source and sink for carbon, urban areas are a frontier in understanding changing environments and the carbon cycle.  The investigator will study the extent to which city trees function as urban air filters, capturing carbon particles from the atmosphere and then depositing them into soils for long-term storage.  Because of carbon?s powerful influence on atmospheric radiative mechanisms, understanding its removal and input into the soil is key to developing and implementing short-term environmental mitigation strategies.  In addition, understanding the factors that contribute to carbon removal in urban areas could help improve air quality for urban residents.  The research will be conducted at the edge of the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area and will quantify the filtration of carbon particulates.  The project will open new pathways into science, technology engineering, and mathematics (STEM) for geography and education majors, and it provides research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students.  Project results will have socioeconomic implications by providing opportunities to impact urban architecture and configuration while understanding the complex urban forms that drive biogeochemical patterns and processes.

The investigator will quantify rates, pathways, and determinants of carbon deposition at fine spatial scales in a rapidly growing city that is representative of many urban areas in semi-arid regions of the world.  The investigator will explore answers to three core questions:  (1) What is the spatial variability in the deposition rates of black carbon on urban tree canopies?  (2) What is the role of throughfall and litterfall in the flux of carbon to the soil?  (3) What are the urban form components that control spatial patterns of black carbon deposition?  High-resolution light detection and ranging (LiDAR) data, geospatial data, and field-measured vegetation characteristics will be integrated to determine the most important factors contributing to spatial variability in the filtering of carbon particulates.  A statistical model will be developed to provide estimates of carbon removal by trees at the city scale.  The LiDAR-based scaling approach is potentially transformative, because it has broad applicability to a range of scientific questions across diverse ecosystems.

por.por_cntn:
Cities are a significant source of elemental carbon to the atmosphere. Colloquially referred to as ‘soot’, elemental carbon is a component of fine particulate matter and an air pollutant that is both a powerful climate-forcing agent and a threat to human health. This NSF CAREER award project quantified how much soot urban trees can capture on their leaves from the air––effectively taking soot out of urban airways––and where in cities tree canopies capture the most. The research was conducted in the City of Denton, Texas, in the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area.

 

The research found that urban tree canopies collect four times more soot than what is measured in rainwater, another major pathway by which soot leaves the atmosphere. Remarkably, estimates indicate that oak trees can accumulate up to 3.5 tons of soot per year, equivalent to ∼32% of the local population's vehicle soot emissions. While tree canopies are efficient at capturing soot pollution, tree species and location matter. Trees located in areas with high stop-and-go traffic, such as bus stops, four-way stops, and intersections, and in areas with high road density collect more soot on their canopies than in areas distant from these sources. 

 

Eventually, some of the soot intercepted by tree canopies falls to the ground, where it can become incorporated into and stored in the soil. Measurements conducted in the soils beneath trees and lawns indicate that near roads urban tree soils are hotspots for the storage of soot and that older trees accumulate increasing amounts of soot in soils over time. Taken together, these results underscore the value of urban trees for capturing soot from the air and for storing soot in the ground below.

 

With a view to translate the research findings into concrete tree planting recommendations, data collected as part of the project were used to create maps showing areas where trees have high and low potential to capture soot from the atmosphere. The maps were then used in conjunction with information provided by the city to identify priority areas for planting trees. The maps demonstrate how planners can use this additional layer of data along with other information (for example, information on heat and social vulnerability) to fine-tune where they plant trees. Overall, the research project has advanced knowledge and understanding of urban ecosystems, urban planning, and human-environment interactions.

 

Since its inception, the project has resulted in 13 total publications (10 peer-reviewed articles, one report, one article for secondary school students, and one Introduction to Earth Science manual) and one integrated science-art exhibition. Students and faculty participating in the project delivered or contributed to 10 invited seminar talks, and 32 poster and paper presentations at international, national, and regional conferences.

 

Results have also been disseminated widely to non-academic audiences, including city governments, neighborhood and community organizations, and university and school classrooms via in-person and virtual oral presentations and written materials. The project continues to receive coverage by local, regional, national and international media. 

 

In addition to advancing scientific knowledge, the project has made substantial contributions to mentored research for diverse groups across multiple career stages, to STEM workforce training, and to university curriculum development. Twelve new labs exploring urban environmental issues were implemented in a large enrollment (~1500 students/yr) earth science laboratory at a large Hispanic-Serving Institution. A new lab manual was published. 

 

Over the course of the project, one post-doc, two technicians, two Ph.D. students, four master’s students, one post-baccalaureate student, and 10 undergraduate students participated in the research. Participants gained invaluable field and laboratory skills, professional development skills, and produced multiple scholarly products. For example, students led or contributed to numerous peer-reviewed journal articles led. Eight of these participants entered the STEM workforce and/or a STEM graduate degree program. 

 

This CAREER research project has raised several new intriguing questions about the impacts of soot capture on urban trees and soils, creating ongoing opportunities for collaborative, interdisciplinary research and student mentoring and training. To summarize, this NSF CAREER award project has contributed significantly to scholarly and creative research, training and mentoring, and community outreach.
